visuals.summary: Critique of masculinity, agency, and narrative perspectives in drone thriller novels
visuals.description: The article critiques the representation of masculinity, agency, and narrative perspectives in drone thriller novels, highlighting the dilemmas of storytelling in the context of drone warfare. It discusses how these novels navigate the challenges of point of view and narrative structure amidst themes of remote killing and militarized masculinity.

visuals.summary: Surreal depiction for a poster design by Japanese designer Kazumasa Nagai.
visuals.description: The surreal poster design by Kazumasa Nagai from the late 1970s serves as a visual representation of the concepts explored in the article about Big Data and Digital Humanities. It captures the fusion of reality and abstraction, mirroring the complexities of data visualization and mapping in the digital age.

visuals.summary: Artwork 'The Connoisseur' by Honoré Daumier.
visuals.description: The artwork 'The Connoisseur' by Honoré Daumier complements the discussion on the historical significance of connoisseurship and critique in the art world. It symbolizes the role of the connoisseur in art evaluation and the evolving dynamics of artistic appreciation over time.

visuals.summary: The Fourth Dimension in Art
visuals.description: Artistic representations and interpretations of the fourth dimension, as discussed in journal articles exploring the philosophical and visual implications of higher-dimensional space.

visuals.summary: The Interplay of Text and Visuals in Art
visuals.description: Visual manifestations of the relationship between text and visuals in art exhibitions, showcasing how textual elements such as wall labels and section texts influence viewers' engagement with artworks.

visuals.summary: Art Historian's Experiment in Attention
visuals.description: Visual exploration of art historian T. J. Clark's detailed study of Nicolas Poussin's paintings, capturing the essence of immersive viewing and the intricate process of looking at art.

visuals.summary: Role of Wall Texts in Museums and Galleries
visuals.description: Visual representation of the significance and complexities of wall texts in museum and gallery settings, illustrating how these texts provide context, information, and interpretation to enhance viewers' understanding of artworks.

visuals.summary: Exploration of form-of-life and its generation within living
visuals.description: The article discusses the concept of form-of-life, generated within living itself, and delves into its relationship with bios and zoè.

visuals.summary: Inseparable life and the relationship between bios and zoè
visuals.description: It touches on the proximity between life and logos in early Christian literature, emphasizing the inseparability of life and form.

visuals.summary: Delving into the mode of being just or beautiful
visuals.description: The text discusses how the mode in which someone is affected by justice or beauty is what truly moves us, emphasizing the ethical aspect of form-of-life.

visuals.summary: The problem of form-of-life as an ethical and aesthetic dilemma
visuals.description: It highlights the emergence of form-of-life as an ethical and aesthetic issue in Western thought, proposing an ontological dimension to address the concept.

visuals.summary: A Line in the Sand: The Frontier as a Ground of Reinscription
visuals.description: The artwork by Gordon Bennett titled 'Home Decor (Preston + De Stijl = Citizen) Dance the Boogieman Blues' explores the concept of the frontier as a space of reinscription and territorial authority. It reflects on the historical and contemporary implications of marking boundaries and the power dynamics involved.

visuals.summary: Evolution of art criticism in the face of changing artistic practices
visuals.description: The artwork 'Yard: Overhead View' by Allan Kaprow captures the essence of the evolution of art criticism in response to changing artistic practices. It symbolizes the shifting relationship between art and life, the struggle for relevance in the art world, and the challenges of defining contemporary art.

visuals.summary: Art's quest for revolution and its entanglement with market forces
visuals.description: The artwork 'Hey Girl! Deconstruct Indigenous Masculinity Roles' by Demian DinéYazhi’ delves into the theme of art's quest for revolution and its entanglement with market forces. It reflects on the challenges of transforming life through art, the failure to realize radical change, and the impact of marketization on artistic expression.

visuals.summary: Contemporary art's struggle for commonality and political change
visuals.description: The artwork 'Hoogah Boogah' by Gordon Hookey symbolizes contemporary art's struggle for commonality and political change. It highlights the fractured nature of the art world, the yearning for a common language to address political needs, and the tension between individual expression and collective action.

visuals.summary: Exploration of queer particularism through art and science
visuals.description: The article discusses the intersection of art, science, and queer theory, emphasizing the importance of materiality and the radical openness of the material world in shaping feminist and queer discourses.

visuals.summary: Transition of photography into pictorial 3-D animation
visuals.description: The text explores the transition of photography into pictorial 3-D animation, highlighting the meticulous and premeditated nature of image creation in this new form of visual art.

visuals.summary: Impact of technology on contemporary photography practices
visuals.description: The article examines the influence of technology on contemporary photography practices, predicting a future where photography will be transformed into a process where images are created based on algorithmic processes and technological interventions.

visuals.summary: Burning of punk memorabilia and self-erasure in street art
visuals.description: The visuals in this article may include images of punk memorabilia being burned, street art being erased with grey paint, and the contrast between rebellious gestures and acts of self-erasure in the art world.

visuals.summary: Materiality and object-oriented art in freeport environments
visuals.description: Visuals could depict artworks in freeports, emphasizing the materiality and object-oriented nature of contemporary art production, showcasing how these artworks exist independently of human interpretation or experience.

visuals.summary: Exploration of high-tech culture and its impact on relationships with technology in the modern world
visuals.description: This visual theme focuses on the intersection of technology, desire, and human relationships in the contemporary era, examining how technology shapes our interactions and influences our daily lives.

visuals.summary: Technocracy and new management techniques in the era of Silicon Valley dominance
visuals.description: This visual theme explores the rise of technocracy and new management philosophies like Agile and Lean, demonstrating how they impact governance and organizational behavior in the digital age of Silicon Valley.

visuals.summary: The convergence of art and technology as the forefront of modern expression and innovation
visuals.description: This visual theme highlights the fusion of art and technology as the cutting edge of contemporary creativity, suggesting that tech itself may be the next vanguard of art, blurring the lines between high art and high technology.

visuals.summary: 3-D printable scan file of Venus of Willendorf.
visuals.description: Rendering of the 3-D printable scan file of Venus of Willendorf, a statue dating back to c. 28,000 B.C.E - 25,000 B.C.

visuals.summary: Silicon Valley's industrial landscape and environmental impact.
visuals.description: Images of toxic waste sites such as 844 E. Charleston Road and Fairchild Semiconductor facility, showcasing the environmental repercussions of the tech industry in Silicon Valley.

visuals.summary: A vision of the future of work and mobility in an asynchronous world
visuals.description: The video advertisement 'Bits and Atoms' by Uber illustrates the company's grand narrative of technology and mobility. It portrays a platform utopia where asynchrony enables an effortless and frictionless people-first mobility system, hinting at the potential impact of asynchrony on future work structures.

visuals.summary: The evolution of management methodologies towards sublime administration
visuals.description: The article discusses how management methodologies like agile, lean, and holacracy embody a form of sublime administration that aims to distribute authority and optimize productivity in an asynchronous work environment. It explores how these methods reconfigure human-organization relationships and reshape labor processes.

visuals.summary: Personal story involving a hand-carved deer and a handwritten note, symbolizing the intersection of love, technology, and communication.
visuals.description: A visual representation of a hand-carved deer and a handwritten note, illustrating the themes of love, technology, and communication discussed in the article.

visuals.summary: Diagram illustrating the evolution of management theories from Taylorism to emotional management and the emphasis on teamwork in modern workplaces.
visuals.description: A visual diagram showcasing the progression of management theories from Taylorism to emotional management, highlighting the importance of teamwork and emotional intelligence in contemporary work environments.

visuals.summary: Artistic interventions in corporate settings, showcasing historical precedents and the impact of artists as consultants on organizational dynamics.
visuals.description: An artistic representation depicting the role of artists as consultants within corporate environments, exploring historical instances and the influence of artistic engagements on organizational structures.

visuals.summary: Artistic exploration of digital infrastructure
visuals.description: The visual component could showcase digital artworks inspired by the exploration of digital aesthetics and infrastructure in art, reflecting the modernist and non-modernist approaches discussed in the article. It could include visual representations of the Web's infrastructure, Internationalized Domain Names, and Unicode characters.

visuals.summary: Political implications of internet shutdowns
visuals.description: Visual representations could depict the impact of internet shutdowns on communication and resistance movements, using symbols and imagery to convey the power dynamics and control associated with such actions. It could include artworks symbolizing censorship, control, and the struggle for internet freedom.

visuals.summary: Contra-internet and alternative networking platforms
visuals.description: Visuals could portray the concept of contra-internet through artistic interpretations of antiwebs, mesh networking devices, and the paranodes as spaces beyond the network form. It could include creative depictions of network militancy, utopian alternatives to the internet, and the emergence of new forms of digital connectivity.

visuals.summary: Artifacts (from the series Centers of the Curved Space)
visuals.description: Artwork by Francisco Infante-Arana and Nonna Gorunova from 1979, reflecting the influence of Russian cosmism on art with a focus on the historical avant-garde and futuristic art movements.

visuals.summary: Aliens: Variant, 1974. From the series The Inhabitants of Distant Planets
visuals.description: Artwork by Alexander Labas from 1974, showcasing the impact of Russian cosmism on intuitive artists and Eastern spirituality, depicting utopian subjects and exploring the theme of immortality.

visuals.summary: Voyage to Saturn, 2004. Performance
visuals.description: Performance art piece by Collective Actions in 2004, delving into cosmological subjects and human resurrection, reflecting on the space race and the exploration of outer space.

visuals.summary: Irrational Forces of the Unknown, 2010. Installation
visuals.description: Installation by Elena Elagina and Igor Makarevich from 2010, inspired by Russian cosmism and Federov's doctrine, exploring themes of humanity's evolution, ascent, and the unification of the divine and human.

visuals.summary: Tsiolkovsky, Second Advent, 2015-2016. Mixed media
visuals.description: Artwork by Arseny Zhilyaev from 2015-2016, confronting cosmism head-on with a project about the future museums entangled with the universe, reflecting on the impact of cosmism on contemporary art.

visuals.summary: Tentacular Thinking: Anthropocene, Capitalocene, Chthulucene
visuals.description: Artwork exploring the concept of the Chthulucene as an alternative narrative to the Anthropocene, highlighting generative joy, terror, and collective thinking.

visuals.summary: Abnormal Encephalization in the Age of Machine Learning
visuals.description: Art project delving into the concept of artificial intelligence as animism for the rich or a form of computational animism, discussing abnormal encephalization and the age of machine learning.

visuals.summary: Art project on a container ship exploring the interaction between artists and crew members.
visuals.description: The art project involves an artist embarking on a container ship residency, interacting with the crew members and exploring the dynamics of corporate sponsorship, institutional critique, and the commercialization of art. It discusses the challenges faced by the artist in negotiating the demands of the corporate sponsor and the implications of blending art with commercial interests on board the ship.

visuals.summary: Merge of distinct concepts in artwork
visuals.description: Visual representation of merging distinct concepts and ideas in art creations, symbolizing the blending of cultural, philosophical, and social issues in artistic expression.

visuals.summary: Challenging traditional art norms
visuals.description: Artwork depicting the challenge of traditional labels and norms in the art industry, exploring themes of queerness, identity, and societal expectations in artistic representation.

visuals.summary: Art as a tool for social change
visuals.description: Visual representation of art as a medium for social commentary, highlighting the role of artists in addressing societal issues, political activism, and advocating for marginalized communities.

visuals.summary: Community support in the art world
visuals.description: Artistic community depicted in the artwork, showcasing the role of community building in providing support, inspiration, and a platform for artists to engage in dialogues about art and identity.

visuals.summary: Exploration of personal and artistic identities
visuals.description: Artwork exploring the complexity of personal and artistic identities, including themes of gender, sexuality, ethnicity, and the impact of societal expectations on individual expression.

visuals.summary: The evolving landscape of social media platforms and their impact on users.
visuals.description: Visual representation showcasing the various social media platforms, their features, and the impact they have on users' behavior, privacy, and perception. The visual could include icons or graphics symbolizing different social media sites and their associated controversies or societal implications.

visuals.summary: The complexities of archival interpretations and the construction of historical narratives.
visuals.description: Visual depiction illustrating the multifaceted nature of archives, including selective curation, interpretation biases, and the influence of power dynamics. The visual could incorporate images representing archives, documents, and the process of historical interpretation to convey the intricate relationship between archives, history, and societal narratives.

visuals.summary: Representation of neofascism's impact on society and culture through art
visuals.description: Visual artwork depicting the influence of neofascism and right-wing populism on society and culture, exploring themes of political manipulation, exclusion, and the aestheticization of politics. The artwork aims to provoke critical reflection on the dangers of neofascist ideologies and the role of art in challenging oppressive regimes.

visuals.summary: Visual interpretation of art as an alternative currency in a fragmented society
visuals.description: Visual representation of art as an alternative currency in a fragmented society where economic instability and inequality prevail. The artwork reflects the juxtaposition of art's perceived stability amidst financial crises and social disparities, highlighting the complexities of art's value and its relationship to broader socio-economic issues.

visuals.summary: Artistic expression symbolizing resistance against authoritarian regimes and oppressive systems
visuals.description: Artistic creation symbolizing resistance against authoritarian regimes and oppressive systems through reimagining art's autonomy and value processes. The artwork conveys a message of collective empowerment and solidarity in challenging derivative fascisms, advocating for transformative practices within the art world to combat inequality and promote sustainable art communities.

visuals.summary: Illustration from 'Varney the Vampire' symbolizing conservative critique of the Enlightenment.
visuals.description: An illustration from 'Varney the Vampire' is used to represent the conservative criticism of the Enlightenment era. It visually conveys the idea of the aristocratic vampire as a metaphor for the unvanquished power of prejudice and the hidden ambiguities within Enlightenment ideals.

visuals.summary: Film still from 'Taxi Driver' depicting themes of protest and disenchantment.
visuals.description: A film still from 'Taxi Driver' is utilized to showcase themes of protest and disenchantment in society. It visually captures the mood of societal unrest and disillusionment, reflecting the article's discussion on political ignorance and civic inadequacy.

visuals.summary: Visual representation of the dichotomy between oppressed and oppressors in 'Funny Games'.
visuals.description: A scene from 'Funny Games' is depicted to illustrate the dichotomy between the oppressed and the oppressors. The image conveys the idea of unconditional violence directed towards a middle-class family, highlighting the underlying tensions within societal power dynamics.

visuals.summary: Artistic depiction of social segregation and institutional intervention in urban ghettos.
visuals.description: An artistic representation of social segregation and institutional intervention in urban ghettos is presented. The artwork symbolizes the complexities of addressing social issues within marginalized communities and the challenges of bridging the gap between privileged institutions and underprivileged groups.

visuals.summary: Visual metaphor for the struggle for equality and the necessity of a 'general' decision.
visuals.description: A symbolic visual metaphor is used to represent the struggle for equality and the need for a decisive 'general' decision. The image conveys the idea of a transformative shift from a society of inequality to one of equality, emphasizing the urgency of recognizing the common interest for all individuals.

visuals.summary: The Don Quixote of Our Time: A Painter's Struggle
visuals.description: Illustrates the story of a renowned painter who faces personal dissatisfaction and a sense of insignificance in the global art scene, reflecting on issues of identity, artistic recognition, and cultural relevance.

visuals.summary: Nomadic Shtetl Archive: Remembering Jewish Heritage
visuals.description: Showcases the mobile center of weak resistance against nationalist rewriting of history in Poland, emphasizing the preservation of Jewish heritage and the commemoration of communities lost to tragedy.

visuals.summary: Political Economy, Political Autonomy
visuals.description: The artwork 'Festung Europa I, 2003' by Alice Creischer and Andreas Siekmann is a digital inkjet print that symbolizes the intertwining of political economy and political autonomy. It visually represents the themes of economic growth, social unrest, and the dynamics of power in contemporary society.

visuals.summary: Male Fantasies in Nazi Exploitation Cinema
visuals.description: The film 'Ilsa the She Wolf of the SS' (1975) and its sequels are examples of Nazi exploitation movies that delve into male fantasies of dominance and submission, often portraying sadistic female SS officers as symbols of power and destruction. These films visualize the intersection of gender, sexuality, and fascist ideologies in popular culture.

visuals.summary: Visual representation of the complexity and nuances of populism in global politics
visuals.description: A visual artwork illustrating the intricate web of meanings and interpretations surrounding the term 'populism' in the context of diverse political movements and leaders worldwide.

visuals.summary: Artistic depiction of the impact of Turkey's role as an EU buffer state on human rights and authoritarian tendencies
visuals.description: An artistic portrayal reflecting the ethical and political implications of Turkey's transformation into an EU buffer state, highlighting issues related to human rights violations and authoritarian governance.

visuals.summary: Artistic representation of transdemocracy and the vision for intersectional democratic autonomy
visuals.description: An artistic creation visualizing the concept of transdemocracy and the advocacy for intersectional democratic autonomy, showcasing the potential for new forms of political engagement and power structures.

visuals.summary: Realist Art as a Reflection of Psychological Experience
visuals.description: Artworks that delve into the psychological experiences of artists, portraying reality not as it objectively exists but as it is subjectively experienced. The connection between realism, psychology, and the depiction of internal conflicts and despair in societal contexts.

visuals.summary: Integration of Art with Technology and Documentation
visuals.description: Art pieces that embrace technology, especially the internet, to present art as a practical activity intertwined with the artist's real-life information. The blurring of boundaries between art, documentation, and everyday activities in the digital age.

visuals.summary: Narratives of Discontent and Revolutionary Potential
visuals.description: Artworks that explore themes of discontent with reality, oppression, and societal conflicts, with a focus on psychological narratives that may lead to revolutionary actions. The role of art in revealing hidden realities and challenging the status quo.

visuals.summary: Artwork: Response to the Letter by Jean-Augustin Franquelin
visuals.description: Oil on canvas painting titled 'Response to the Letter' by Jean-Augustin Franquelin, displayed at the Louvre Museum. The artwork captures a historical moment and showcases the artist's skill in conveying emotions and messages through visual art.

visuals.summary: Artwork: The Green Box by Marcel Duchamp
visuals.description: The Green Box, also known as La mariée mise à nu par ses célibataires, même, by Marcel Duchamp is a significant artwork that challenges traditional notions of art. It poses the fundamental question of whether works that are not traditionally considered art can be created, marking a shift in art's development.

visuals.summary: Artwork: Text / Context by Joseph Kosuth
visuals.description: Text / Context, an artwork by Joseph Kosuth exhibited in New York City, presents breakthrough ideas related to the independence of art from aesthetics. It explores the principle of verification and the conceptual independence of art from various disciplines, contributing to the understanding of Conceptual art.

visuals.summary: Metaphysical representation of subjectivity in Descartes' philosophy
visuals.description: Visual depiction of the intricate relationship between substance, essence, and subject in Descartes' philosophical framework. Illustrating the complex interplay of finite and infinite elements within the concept of the subject.

visuals.summary: Futuristic visualization of subject transformation in Afrofuturist narrative
visuals.description: Artistic interpretation of Lilith's journey in Octavia Butler's Lilith's Brood trilogy, showcasing her evolution from a human survivor to a mother of a new, inhuman race. Capturing the themes of alienation, genetic hybridization, and biopolitical agency.

visuals.summary: Digital artwork exploring the intersection of subjectivity and machine intelligence
visuals.description: Abstract digital art piece symbolizing the merging of human subjectivity with machine logic. Reflecting the fusion of human agency and algorithmic governance in the age of data-driven decision-making.

visuals.summary: Community takeover of a tourism complex for sustainable living
visuals.description: Visualizing the peaceful takeover of the Acapulco Diamante tourism complex by displaced families and environmentalists to establish communal forms of living, sustainable habitats, and ecological restoration. The image portrays a transformative act of reclaiming spaces for communal well-being and alternative living practices.

visuals.summary: Activist art collectives reclaiming museums as sites of political struggle
visuals.description: Illustrating the tactics employed by activist art collectives such as Liberate Tate and Decolonize This Place in commandeering museums to challenge capitalist interests, disrupt colonial narratives, and reclaim the cultural commons. The visuals showcase the museum as a terrain of insurgency and counterpower against capitalist exploitation.

visuals.summary: GALA Committee's Art on Melrose Place
visuals.description: The collaborative art created by the GALA Committee for the TV show Melrose Place serves as an example of art's interaction with information and provenance. It showcases how art as rarity can intersect with information abundance, leading to unique opportunities for creating value and authenticity.

visuals.summary: Trump Tower's Derivative Architecture
visuals.description: The derivative architecture of Trump Tower in Manhattan is explored to highlight its minimal familiarity and the concept of architecture as a derivative of design elements. It delves into how architectural structures can reflect cultural influences and societal contexts through their derivative nature.

visuals.summary: Art and Fascism Connection
visuals.description: The connection between contemporary art, hoarding, and the resurgence of fascism is examined to underscore art's function as a form of international monetary sovereignty. It discusses the role of art as a counter-distribution mechanism in the global sociopolitical landscape, reflecting on material validation within the art world.

visuals.summary: Replication of iconic artworks through ceramic plates
visuals.description: Details the process of replicating famous artworks onto ceramic plates at the Ōtsuka Museum of Art in Japan, emphasizing the aim to create long-lasting copies for public display.

visuals.summary: The fusion of art, technology, and corporate sponsorship
visuals.description: Examines the fusion of art, technology, and corporate sponsorship at the Ōtsuka Museum of Art, showcasing how these elements intersect to create a unique art exhibition experience.

visuals.summary: Plastiglomerate Samples: Artistic Exploration
visuals.description: Artistic exploration of plastiglomerate samples collected from Kamilo Beach in Hawai’i showcases the fusion of plastic waste and sand into captivating sculptures. These visual representations of plastiglomerate serve as powerful symbols of human-induced pollution and its enduring impact on natural landscapes. By transforming waste into art, artists draw attention to environmental issues in a thought-provoking and creative manner.

visuals.summary: Ocean Pollution: Microplastics and Marine Ecosystems
visuals.description: The pervasive presence of microplastics in oceans, unseen but detrimental, poses a grave threat to marine ecosystems. Visualizing the impact of plastic pollution on marine life and habitats underscores the urgent need for conservation efforts and responsible waste management practices. Understanding the visual intricacies of ocean pollution sheds light on the interconnectedness of human activities and environmental degradation.

visuals.summary: Plastiglomerate as Geologic Marker: Aesthetic Reflection
visuals.description: Exploring plastiglomerate as a geologic marker offers a unique perspective on human-altered landscapes and ecological transformations. The aesthetic qualities of plastiglomerate, blending synthetic polymers with natural elements, evoke contemplation on the entwined nature of human actions and geological processes. By highlighting the intersection of art, geology, and environmental impact, plastiglomerate serves as a metaphor for the complex relationships between humans and the Earth.

visuals.summary: Geontopower vs. Biopower
visuals.description: Visual representation contrasting geontopower and biopower in a diagram showcasing the governance of Life and Nonlife in late liberalism.

visuals.summary: Global collapse and subjectivity
visuals.description: Illustration depicting the themes of impending global collapse and the call for a new subjectivity in the face of rightist movements.

visuals.summary: Illustration: Ontology of Digital Objects
visuals.description: A visual representation depicting the interplay between digital objects, metadata schemes, and the ontology of digital existence, symbolizing the complex relationships and hierarchies within the digital realm.

visuals.summary: Artwork: Sovereignty of the Citizen
visuals.description: An artistic depiction capturing the essence of citizen sovereignty, showcasing the balance between individual freedom and collective equality, and the empowerment of citizens in shaping political decisions and governance.

visuals.summary: Art Installation: Hyperbolic Proposition
visuals.description: An immersive art installation inspired by the hyperbolic proposition in the Declaration of Rights, inviting viewers to reflect on the complexities of citizenship, equality, and the transformative power of revolutionary ideals in shaping societies.

visuals.summary: Billboard Displaying U.S. National Debt
visuals.description: A billboard installed in 1989 by a real estate developer displaying the U.S. gross national debt and each family's share of it. This visual representation serves as a reminder of the economic implications of national debt and distribution of social surplus.

visuals.summary: Protest Culture and Digital Archive
visuals.description: The editorial mentions the role of protest culture, political graffiti, fashion, and dance in movements like #BlackLivesMatter. It also highlights the creation of a vast digital archive and social media commentary as visual elements representing modern activism.

visuals.summary: In Pursuit of Bling Installation
visuals.description: An art installation by Otobong Nkanga utilizing minerals to critique colonial violence and expose the obscured connections between spaces of abundance and scarcity, challenging the Western aesthetic culture's disposition of the subject.

visuals.summary: United Nations Image
visuals.description: An illustrative image used to highlight the tragic reality of migrant deaths in the Mediterranean Sea, reflecting the ethical indifference towards human lives and the systemic violence embedded in modern knowledge and categorization.

visuals.summary: Iceberg Slim Portrait
visuals.description: A portrayal of Iceberg Slim, a key figure in black literature, representing the complex themes of racial identity, decadence, and social critique within the context of African American experience and cultural production.

visuals.summary: Artworks by David Hammons
visuals.description: The artworks by David Hammons, such as 'Caution' and 'Defend Your Walk', utilize body prints and abstract material applications to comment on the exposure to violence and the precarity of black life, challenging traditional representations and engaging with the complexities of black corporeality.

visuals.summary: Sadie Barnette's reimagining of FBI files
visuals.description: Sadie Barnette's art installations, including 'My Father's FBI File, Project 1' and 'Untitled (Dad's Mug shot)', reinterpret her father's FBI surveillance files, employing material interventions like wheat-pasted wallpaper and pencil drawings to disrupt the visual representation of state surveillance and criminalization of black activists.

visuals.summary: Sonic resistance and community solidarity through music and spoken word
visuals.description: The visual representation showcases a diverse array of musical elements such as records, lyrics, and performers intertwined to symbolize the power of sonic resistance and communal solidarity. It captures the essence of music as a transformative force in organizing movements and inspiring collective action.

visuals.summary: Visualizing the Black Power movement's revolutionary impact on societal change
visuals.description: The visual concept illustrates the essence of the Black Power movement in Detroit, portraying a dynamic interplay between socialist strategies, black nationalism, and grassroots activism. It visually represents the call for black political power and self-determination as pivotal elements in the quest for social change.

visuals.summary: Artistic Representation of Black Power
visuals.description: Artistic representation visualizing the concept of Black Power in the United States through symbols, historical references, and power dynamics. Reflects the themes of liberation, power struggle, and social change in a visual medium.

visuals.summary: Visual Interpretation of Black Lives Matter
visuals.description: Visual interpretation capturing the essence of the Black Lives Matter movement and its temporal dynamics. Utilizes artistic elements to convey the transformative power of the movement, entanglement with the Anthropocene crisis, and the call for social change.

visuals.summary: Spatial Visualization of Temporal Intersections
visuals.description: Spatial visualization representing the intersections of time and space with race, depicting the complexities of temporal dynamics and their impact on social structures. Incorporates visual elements to illustrate the intertwined relationship between time, space, and racial hierarchies.

visuals.summary: Artistic Expression of Revolutionary Time
visuals.description: Artistic expression capturing the essence of revolutionary time as a cyclical liberation process, featuring elements of historic events, calls for reparations, and visions of a transformed future. Conveys the cyclical nature of liberation struggles through visual storytelling.

visuals.summary: Visual Representation of Catastrophic Time and Water Symbolism
visuals.description: Visual representation exploring catastrophic time and its impact on human revolutionary time, with a focus on water symbolism and its connection to natural disasters and historical events. Utilizes artistic elements to convey the complexities of temporal dynamics and environmental issues.

visuals.summary: Interpreting the divided self through art
visuals.description: The editorial 'Issue #80 Editorial' visualizes the concept of the divided self through artistic representations, highlighting the struggle for self-control and the presence of heteronomous selves. It presents a unique perspective on the artist's role in producing a surplus self that defies traditional human boundaries.

visuals.summary: Exploring the inhuman surplus in contemporary art
visuals.description: The editorial 'Issue #80 Editorial' explores the inhuman surplus in contemporary art, referencing machines, women, and demons aligning on the dark side of the screen. It questions the boundaries of countability and the blurred lines between human and non-human entities in the artistic realm.

visuals.summary: Artistic representation of rituals and symbolic invocations related to the female demon Babalon.
visuals.description: Visual artwork depicting Jack Parsons performing rituals to invoke Babalon, showcasing symbolic elements like fire, blood, and mystical symbolism associated with the transition to a new age through the invocation of the female demon.

visuals.summary: Visual interpretation of the human body's demands for equality and its interaction with changing ideologies.
visuals.description: Artistic representation illustrating the human body's demand for equality, contrasting with changing ideologies represented by symbols like beggar, consumer, owner, or nothing. The artwork captures the essence of human adaptability and the conflict with fixed definitions imposed by ideologies.

visuals.summary: Dmitri Prigov's Poetic Performances
visuals.description: The article discusses how Dmitry Prigov's performances blurred the boundaries between poetry and visual art, highlighting his transition from poetic recitals to image production during the Perestroika era.

visuals.summary: Exploration of Nothingness in Art
visuals.description: The article examines the concept of nothingness in art as showcased in exhibitions like 'Voids' and the virtual No Show Museum, contrasting the universal claim of nothingness with the particularity of black experiences depicted in works like David Hammons's 'Concerto in Black and Blues.'

visuals.summary: A film still from Julie Dash’s 'Daughters of the Dust' highlighting cultural heritage and storytelling in the context of Black identity.
visuals.description: The image captures a scene from the film 'Daughters of the Dust' by Julie Dash, showcasing the representation of cultural heritage and storytelling within the narrative of Black identity and history.

visuals.summary: A plate featuring the Wedgwood abolition emblem 'Am I not a Man and a Brother?' symbolizing the abolitionist movement and the fight against slavery.
visuals.description: The plate showcases the iconic Wedgwood abolition emblem 'Am I not a Man and a Brother?' symbolizing the abolitionist movement and advocating for the rights and equality of enslaved individuals.

visuals.summary: Watercolor drawing showing a papilloma springing from the neighborhood of the left vocal cord, emphasizing medical illustration and anatomical details.
visuals.description: The watercolor drawing depicts a papilloma originating from the left vocal cord region, highlighting the intricate details of medical illustration and anatomical structures for educational purposes.

visuals.summary: Woodcut illustration from the medical handbook 'Zhengzhi tuzhu houke' featuring throat conditions, showcasing historical medical practices and visual representations.
visuals.description: The woodcut illustration from the medical handbook 'Zhengzhi tuzhu houke' focuses on throat conditions, providing insights into historical medical practices and visual representations used for educational and diagnostic purposes.

visuals.summary: Auratic anchoring in visual art
visuals.description: Explores the concept of auratic anchoring in visual art, using the example of Thomas Demand's images to discuss the creation of a new form of aura based on absorption into an alternative reality.

visuals.summary: The role of introspection in art creation
visuals.description: Discusses the role of introspection in art creation, highlighting the importance of self-awareness and individual strength in lowering ego barriers and fostering cooperation, drawing on philosophical ideas like Kant's monadology.

visuals.summary: Circular montage in film and art
visuals.description: Examines the concept of circular montage in film and art, emphasizing the combination of elements that are not typically linked and the importance of emphasizing details and overall history in exhibitions and artistic projects.

visuals.summary: Neoreactionaries and the Unhappy Consciousness
visuals.description: Artwork depicting the clash between Enlightenment values and neoreactionary ideology, symbolizing the struggle with feelings of contradiction and loss in the modern West.

visuals.summary: Asian Futurism: Speculative Art and Technology
visuals.description: Visual representation of Asian Futurism exploring the fusion of art and technology in a global context, highlighting the complexities of otherness across time and cultures.

visuals.summary: Artistic expressions challenging global systems and ethical dilemmas
visuals.description: Artworks and projects that challenge global systems, ethical dilemmas, and the boundaries between reason and sense. Artists address justice, identity, and the interplay between art, law, and social structures through aesthetic presentations.

visuals.summary: Visual narratives capturing the struggle of the Losheng Preservation Movement
visuals.description: Visual narratives documenting the struggle of the Losheng Preservation Movement to save a sanatorium housing Hansen's Disease patients from demolition. Images depicting the historical context, protests, and the human rights issues surrounding the preservation movement.

visuals.summary: Artistic representations of colonial modernity and labor flexibilization
visuals.description: Artistic representations exploring the impact of colonial modernity on labor practices, social exclusion, and the suppression of communist imagination. Visual narratives challenging neoliberal policies, labor flexibilization, and internal colonialism in contemporary society.

visuals.summary: Captivating exploration of movement and images in Arthur Jafa's short film.
visuals.description: Arthur Jafa's film 'Love is the Message, The Plan is Death' intricately weaves historical black-and-white images, body choreography, violence, and music to provoke viewers into considering the relationship between motion and movement in art.

visuals.summary: Evocative analysis of the Anthropocene and its implications for Life and Nonlife.
visuals.description: The article delves into the Anthropocene as a pivotal geological era where human forces dominate planetary existence, challenging the distinction between Life and Nonlife. It explores the concept of geontopower and its effects on governance and scale.

visuals.summary: Provocative introduction to the figures of the Desert, the Animist, and the Virus in disrupting current existence.
visuals.description: The article presents the Desert as a figure emphasizing the threat to Life, the Animist seeing equivalence among all forms of life, and the Virus as an antagonistic agent disrupting existing arrangements. It discusses the impact of these figures on governance and the boundaries between Life and Nonlife.
